entry.title: Multiple SAP HANA Systems on One Host
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission-critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that must be protected from failures. Business-critical production HANA databases require a well-designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) plan to ensure business continuity and minimize downtimeA primary (active) HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). HSR continuously replicates data to an alternate instance to ensure that changes persist in the event of a primary instance failure.

SAP does support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDS) on a single production SAP HANA hardware installation (or single virtual machine). 

Multiple SAP HANA systems on one host are also known as Multiple Components on One System (MCOS).

SAP support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on a single production SAP HANA host. This is restricted to single-host / scale-up scenarios only.  One Hardware which can be segregated for two HANA tenant installations. Filesystem e can be also be segregated which allows us to do maintenance separately.

Few considerations:

  • RAM:

SAP HANA is memory intensive. Sufficient RAM is crucial for optimal performance, potentially 64GB or 128GB or more depending on the data size and workload.

  • CPU:

Adequate CPU resources are needed to handle the processing demands of multiple HANA instances.

  • Disk Space:

Ensure sufficient disk space for the installation binaries, data volumes, log volumes, and trace files for all instances/tenants.

  • Network:

Plan for network configuration, especially if using a multi-host setup or if the databases need to communicate with other systems.

Production support is restricted to SAP HANA 1.0 SPS 09 (and higher) or SAP HANA 2.0 due to the availability of some resource management parameters (for example affinity). Be aware that running multi-SID on one SAP HANA host may impact performance of various types of operations, as contention for computing resources may occur (memory, cpu, i/o, ...).

SAP strongly recommends performing requisite testing in any project before going live; in general, stress/volume testing is recommended in order to provide good indicators of expected performance. When operating a system that features a multi-SID deployment, SAP recommends to actively make use of the resource management features of SAP HANA (e.g. parameters controlling memory limits, and influencing utilization of CPU cores, etc.) in order to optimize performance.

Business critical Production HANA DB’s require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) for business continuity and allow a SAP technical team to minimize the downtime and increase the application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR).

SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance. In Public Clouds the secondary HANA database instance can either exist within the same region (different Availability Zone) or in a separate region.

 

 

 

SAP systems that are critical to business continuity require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) framework to maximise application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance.

To achieve a near zero Recovery Time Objective (RTO), it is necessary for the primary and secondary HANA database instances to have a similar memory capacity. However, if a higher RTO is acceptable, it is possible to operate the secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint. This can result in considerable cost savings for compute, either by choosing a smaller instance size or leveraging excess memory on the secondary to operate other SAP HANA database workloads.

The reduced memory requirement in the secondary HANA node is achieved by configuring the secondary to not load HANA column data into main memory. A restart is required before promoting it to be primary, at which time it is assumed that the full memory requirement is available. The actual memory demand on secondary host is highly dependent on the HANA System Replication (HSR) configuration and production data change rate. Even by disabling HANA column table loading, the memory demands on the secondary host can go beyond 60% of the actual production HANA memory usage. If the secondary instance is not sized correctly, this can lead to out-of-memory crashes and reduced resilience.

This blog aims at providing a detailed guidance on how to size the secondary HANA database instance while operating with reduced memory footprint with examples for multiple deployment scenarios.

Architecture

There are two common architectures for deploying a secondary HANA database with a lean, or reduced memory footprint in single Hardware.  In this blog we differentiate between them with the terms ‘smaller secondary’ and ‘shared secondary’. Smaller secondary is where the infrastructure is sized smaller than the primary, and then re-sized on takeover. This is sometimes referred to as Pilot Light DR as in the blog Rapidly recover mission-critical systems in a disaster. Shared secondary is where the unused memory is utilized by a non-production or sacrificial instance. SLES documentation refers to this as ‘Cost Optimized Scenario‘.

In both these scenarios, preload of column tables is disabled on the secondary HANA database. The specific configuration to implement this change is to set the HANA database parameter preload_column_tables to false. This configuration needs to be changed to ‘true’ before promoting this instance as primary. Given the manual intervention required and the time taken following a takeover to load the column tables before the HANA database is open for SQL connections, these scenarios are more relevant for a Disaster Recovery (DR) than a High Availability (HA) solution.

Shared secondary

A common use case for a shared secondary scenario is to operate an active quality (QAS) instance along with the secondary HANA database instance on the same host, also called MCOS (Multiple Components One System). This setup requires additional storage to operate the additional instance(s). During a takeover, the instance with lower priority (QAS) can be shutdown to make the underlying host resources available for production workloads.

 

 

For both the scenarios, the secondary HANA database instance configuration is set to preload_column_tables = false. The default value of this parameter is ‘true’ and has to be explicitly changed on the secondary instance to operate with reduced memory. This change is made in HANA database configuration file (global.ini) located in the file path (/hana/shared/<SID>/global/hdb/custom/config).

HANA SR Operation modes

The two operation modes supported by HANA System Replication (HSR) to setup a secondary system are logreplay and delta_datashipping. A high-level comparison between logreplay and delta_datashipping operation modes is presented below.

SAP HANA System Replication Operation Modes

#

Criteria

logreplay

delta_datashipping

1

Operational Behavior

Logs are shipped and continuously applied on the secondary system.

Delta data is shipped from the primary to the secondary occasionally (default 10 min). Logs are only shipped, not applied, until a takeover.

2

Recovery Time

Shorter takeover window, as logs are applied continuously until a failure occurs.

Relatively higher takeover time.

3

Data Transfer Needs

Only logs are shipped, resulting in comparatively lower data transfer needs.

Transfer of both delta data and logs adds to higher data transfers.

4

Network Bandwidth

Due to reduced data transfers, this mode requires relatively lower bandwidth between sites.

This mode requires higher bandwidth between sites.

5

Memory Footprint on DR Instance

Significantly higher memory is required as the column store needs to be loaded for faster delta merge.

The memory footprint is much smaller because the column store isn't loaded into the main memory when column preload is disabled.

6

Multi-tier Replication

Supported

Supported

7

Multi-target Replication

Supported

Not supported

8

Secondary Time Travel

Supported

Not supported

 

 

It is worth noting that in a 3-Tier replication setup, a mix of operation modes is not supported. For example if the primary and secondary HANA database instances are configured to use logreplay for HSR, then delta_datashipping operation mode cannot be used between the secondary and tertiary systems and vice-versa.

SAP Guidance on disabling column preload

The actual memory usage on the secondary host is dependent on the HANA replication operation mode configuration and the preload setting for column tables. Hence it is important to understand the sizing requirements for different operation modes in a HANA System Replication setup. The below chart is an excerpt from SAP Note : 1999880 – FAQ: SAP HANA System Replication (SAP Support Portal login required)

 

As per the above guidance, even with preload = off, the minimum memory requirements for operation mode ‘logreplay’ also factors in the column store memory size of tables with modifications . As a rule of thumb, consider the size of column store tables with data modified in the previous 30 days from current date of evaluation.

SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA provides a collection of SQL scripts that can be used for analysing various administration and performance aspects of SAP HANA database. With minor changes to one of the scripts from this collection, titled ‘HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime’, it is possible to provide a rough estimate for the minimum memory required to accommodate these tables. For exact steps of executing this script, refer to the ‘Additional information’ section at the end of this blog.

In the following sections, the examples provide details on how to evaluate sizing when deployed in a Shared secondary scenario. Although not shown, a similar sizing exercise is applicable to the Smaller secondary scenario, without the additional considerations of running a second HANA database instance (for example QAS) on the same host.

Option 1 – HSR with Operation Mode: logreplay

In the following example, the primary and secondary production HANA database instances are deployed on two 9TiB High Memory instances. The secondary instance host also hosts a Quality Assurance (QAS) HANA Database Instance. To be able to deploy these instances, the global_allocation_limit for all the three HANA database instances (PRD-Primary, PRD-Secondary, QAS) needs to be evaluated. Following section illustrates how to derive these values.

 

 

 

In the subsequent sections, Global Allocation Limit is referred as ‘GAL’.

  • GAL for Primary instance

On the Primary instance, global_allocation_limit is not set in this example (default value=0 and unit is MB). A default value does not limit the amount of physical memory that can be used by the database. However, as per the SAP Note 1681092 – Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), maximum allocation to HANA database by operating system follows the rule of 90% of the first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

  • GAL for Secondary instance

SAP’s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and logreplay operation mode is, ‘Row store size + Column store memory size of tables with modifications + 50 GB’. As an example, on the primary instance, the SQL script ‘HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime’ was executed and the column tables with modifications for the previous 30 days is identified as 3077 GB. For detailed steps of executing this script, refer to the ‘Additional information’ section of this blog.

 

 

Similarly, using SQL script ‘HANA_Memory_Overview’ from SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA, the memory requirements for ‘Row store’ can be determined. An example value of 153 GB is considered for the following evaluation.

Memory required (min) = Row store size

                        + Column store memory size of tables with modifications

                        + 50 GB

Ex: (153 + 3077 + 50) GB = 3280 GB

GAL for DR = 3280 GB^

  ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Note: This value provides the minimum sizing guidance only. It is recommended to allocate additional headroom of 10-20% of this value to accommodate any immediate spike in column store table modifications.

Similarly, global_allocation_limit (GAL) has to be set for the second HANA database instance (QAS) running on the DR site. According to  the SAP Note 1681092 – Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), the sum total of all HANA database allocation limits on a particular host should not exceed 90% of first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

Σ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)] ≤ {(0.9 * 64) + [0.97 * (Phys Mem GB - 64)]}

Applying this guidance to our example of 9 TiB(9896 GB)  bare metal instance is as follows.

Σ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤  {[0.9 * 64] + [0.97 * (9896 - 64)]} GB

                          ≤  9595 GB

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). As the HANA DR instance memory sizing is derived at 3280 GB, the remaining size can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Σ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤ 9595 GB

Σ [ 3280 GB  + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤ 9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 6314 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Option 2 – HSR with Operation Mode: delta_datashipping

This section provides an overview of HANA System Replication deployed with ‘delta_datashipping’ operation mode and the procedure to evaluate the memory sizing for each individual instance.

 

 

 

  • GAL for Secondary instance

 

SAP’s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and delta_datashipping operation mode is as follows. Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (Row store size + 20 GB)]

Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (153 + 20 GB)]

GAL for DR: The minimum required value for GAL_DR = 173 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). In the previous step, secondary HANA database instance memory sizing is derived at 173 GB, the remaining size on the host can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Σ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]   ≤ 9595 GB

Σ [ 173 GB   + (GAL_QAS)] ≤  9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 9422 GB^

   ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Conclusion

This blog highlights that the cost savings of deploying a secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint may not be realized with logreplay operation mode. This is because of the higher memory demands of column store being loaded into the main memory of secondary HANA database and occurs irrespective of the column table preload setting. This behavior is by design for continuous log replay. In addition, there is a requirement to constantly monitor column store data growth on the primary and adapt memory allocations on the secondary to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) issues on secondary. The operation mode delta_datashipping facilitates better cost savings in comparison to logreplay while disabling the preload of column tables on secondary HANA database instance. However, this choice comes with limitations which may include a higher recovery time and an increased demand for network bandwidth between the replication sites.

Opting for delta_datashipping is usually a trade-off between cost considerations and other limitations of this operation mode as explained in this blog. With relaxed RTO requirements and higher network bandwidth between the replication sites, the use of ‘delta_datashipping’ can be promoted. Also, with larger database instances, the potential for cost savings is higher. This is because the memory footprint on the secondary has a minimum requirement of row store memory and buffer requirements even for smaller database instances. The association between various factors that influence the choice of a particular operation mode and the potential for cost benefits with delta_datashipping option are represented in the following diagram. These factors are independent of each other and can individually influence the ability to use ‘delta_datashipping’ and thereby the cost benefits.

It is also important to understand that the memory requirement calculation for the secondary and subsequent setting of global_allocation_limit, is an iterative process. As the production database size grows, eventually the column store demand for delta merge also grows on the secondary instance. Hence, the memory allocations of secondary and optionally, other HANA database instances provisioned on the same hardware should be monitored periodically and also after mass data loads, go-lives and SAP system specific life-cycle events.

Additional Information

Following are the steps to execute the SAP SQL script.

  1. Download the file SQLStatements.zip which is an attachment to SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA
  2. Unzip the file and identify the SQL script named HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime_2.00.x+.txt (for HANA 1.0, choose a different version of the same script).
  3. Modify the script with the following two changes.

TOUCH_TYPE

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'TOUCH_TYPE' and enter the value as 'MODIFY'

Ex: 'MODIFY' TOUCH_TYPE,       /* ACCESS, SELECT, MODIFY */

BEGIN_TIME

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'BEGIN_TIME' and key in the value as 'C-D30'

Ex: 'C-D30' BEGIN_TIME,

  1. Execute the script on the HANA Production tenant DB using any of the SQL editors of SAP HANA Cockpit, SAP HANA Studio and DBACOCKPIT or the tool hdbsql.
  2. Identify the output under the column ‘MEM_GB’ for the column store size that has been modified in the previous 30 days from the date of script execution.

entry.title: Using the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Status App
entry.content:
SAP Note 1257308 - FAQ: Using EarlyWatch Alert provides preliminary information about the Status App. The app tracks the status of the SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) from the arrival of service data through all processing steps at SAP. This app is intended for administrators to troubleshoot the EWA process. This blog will provide a more detailed description of the Status App functionality.

EWA session data can be sent to SAP through various methods. The EWA session data can be sent directly to SAP through the HTTP destination SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL (via SAP-SUPPORT_PARCELBOX) from either an ABAP managed system or an SAP Solution Manager system. Additionally, any EWA session data for systems managed by the ECS team are sent via their SAP Focused Run systems on SAP side to be processed. The following Notes and KBAs are provided for more information on all three scenarios.

  • 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP
  • 1684537 - EarlyWatch Alert Not Sent to SAP: Troubleshooting Guide - SAP Solution Manager
  • 2930644 - SAP Focused Run: EarlyWatch Alert Troubleshooting Guide - Guided Answer

After sending EWA session data through one of the available methods it can be unclear whether the EWA data was successfully received by SAP or if there was any issue with the EWA session processing. The EWA Status App allows you to follow the status of your EWA report once it’s sent to SAP.

All EWA session data sent to SAP will be available for review in the EWA Status App, here you will find various details about the EWA sessions you have sent.

You can see the date the EWA session data session was sent, if they have been successfully received by SAP, as well as whether the EWA session could be processed successful or has been generated and posted in the EWA workspace.

Since the EWA session data packages sent to SAP are processed in randomly assigned batches for all customers it can take from a few hours to a few days for your EWA result to be available in various SAP applications like the EWA Workspace, Solution Finder, EWA Dashboard, or as a Word document available for download. Using the Status App allows you to track this process without opening a case.

The general fields available in the EWA Status App that are applicable for all system types are the following columns.

  • System
  • Product
  • Sending System Product
  • Data Received at SAP
  • Collected At

The “System” and “Product” columns will list the long and short SID as well as the product version respectively of the EWA target system.

The “Sending System Product” column, however, will display the product version of the system that transferred the session data to SAP. This is most often a Solution Manager or Focused Run system.  

Finally, the “Data Received at SAP” and “Collected at” columns document the date and time the EWA session package was received by SAP as well as when it was collected on the managed system.

Data Transfer Status Details

In the EWA Status App the “Data Transfer Status Details” column can have one of three status’. The status’ are Rejected, Ignored, Success. As you would expect Success simply indicates the EWA session data was successfully transferred to SAP. The other two status’ can be indicative of various errors. I will describe the most common in more detail below.

"Ignored (duplicate)"

This status indicates that the EWA is sent multiple times per week for the same system. You should check to see if the EWA is being sent from both Solution Manager and the managed system. The same checks should be performed for on prem FRUN systems. The EWA could also be sent multiple times per week from the same system. All will result in the same status.

"Ignored (not in allow list)"

This status can be caused by a few errors. However, the most common would be that either the license or maintenance certificate for the system is expired.

Recommendation:

Review the SLICENSE transaction in Solution Manager if used as well as the managed system to ensure both are up to date.

"Rejected (system time in future)"

The system runs with a system time deviating from official time. 

Recommendation:

The System Time can be synced manually by your system Admin. However, it is likely that this is a temporary change for testing purposes and it will sync automatically via Internet. If not working, your Admin can start this sync process at the OS Level.

 

"Rejected (no data)"

The service data that arrived at SAP is either not readable or empty or incomplete and thus important parts are completely missing.

Recommendation:

This would indicate that there are issues with EWA session data collection or service data quality. We recommend reviewing the resolution steps in the KBA 1824881 - Summary of Grey Rated EWA Reports - SAP Solution Manager.

"Rejected (non-productive)"

Only for productive and test systems the EWA is processed at SAP. Based on the system role the service data can be rejected. This is true for managed systems before ST-PI 740 SP23 (ST-PI 2008_1_7xx SP33) more information on the adjusted criteria can be found in SAP Note 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP.

"Rejected (not authorized)"

The technical communication user used for upload is not authorized to upload for this system.

Or

The technical communication user used for upload is not valid anymore.

Or

The user used for upload is not a technical communication user.

Recommendation:

You will need to ensure the S user assigned to both the SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL and SAP-SUPPORT_PACELBOX HTTP destinations is a valid technical user. The following KBA outlines the requirements for the assigned user.

2174416 - Creation and activation of Technical Communication Users - SAP for Me

"Rejected (other reason)"

Create a case with component SV-SCS-EWA-GEN.

"Rejected (content size exceeds limit)"

The service data exceeds the size limit.

"Rejected (unknown system type)"

Supported technical system types are ABAP, HANA, JAVA and BOBJ. When extracting the leading system from the service data either no technical system type was determined, or the technical system type is not supported by EarlyWatch Alert.

Recommendation:

If using Solution Manager it is recommended that you review the system information maintained in LMDB. Ensure the technical system type is maintained and that it is a supported type.

In addition, in some scenarios is may be required to replace the SDCCN service definitions. The following KBA outlines the process and under which circumstances these steps should be performed.

SAP KBA 1765141 - When should the Service Definitions be completely replaced (Delete and Download) using the steps outlined in SAP Note 727998?

"Rejected (data too old)"

The service data that was sent to SAP was collected more than 112 days ago. Such old service data is not processed by SAP.

 

Details on Report Status, Dashboard Status, and Solution Finder Status

These three columns are relatively binary. The Status can either be “Success” or “Missing” / blank. In rare instances you can receive the status “Error (Initialization Failed)”. In this instance a case should be opened in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

The Report Status will be successful when the EWA document has been successfully generated. Until this point this column will remain blank. As mentioned previously it can take from a few hours to several days for your EWA result to be available. If the EWA session data was successfully received by SAP there is no cause for concern if the EWA report is not immediately available.

The same is true of the columns “Dashboard Status” and “Solution Finder Status”. When these applications are fully populated the EWA column status here in the Status App will change to Success. Prior to this the status will remain either blank or have the status “Missing”. Neither status is a cause for concern. If after several days the status of these columns remains unpopulated you should open a case in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

 

2 Billion Record Limit Status and Number Range Forecast Details

This column is system dependent. These checks are in reference to the maximum table size for HANA systems. The maximum table size cannot exceed 2 billion records for a HANA system without detrimental impact to the system.

However, the status “Missing” is most often applied to systems that do not have a HANA component. This information is not relevant to your system if you do not have a HANA Component and is not a cause for concern. You should review the EWA for the affected system to confirm that there is no associated HANA DB.

For HANA systems where this check was not successfully performed the status will instead be “No Forecast”, “Partial Success”, or “Unconfident Forecast”.

These may be a cause for concern and your first steps should be to review the RTCCTOOL recommendations of both the managed system and Solution Manager. You are looking for any red warning objects related to HANA session data, ST-PI, or ST-A/PI.

More information about the exact limitations of HANA are documented in the KBA 2154870 - How-To: Understanding and defining SAP HANA Limitations.

Additionally, more information can be found in the HANA Sizing Blog.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #2 in the Series
entry.content:
In my previous blog, I discussed how SAP HANA Cloud delivers critical business benefits to organizations that migrate their database to the cloud. Advanced features such as multi-model engines allow enterprises to increase productivity and reduce complexity. In a recent study,[1]  IDC calculated that large enterprises can realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud.

Understanding how the specific capabilities of the database benefit your organization is key to helping you justify a cloud modernization initiative. Let’s look at two more capabilities that can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud: infrastructure independence and a next-generation application foundation.

Infrastructure independence

Your database requirements constantly evolve. To keep up with changing business conditions, customer requirements, and user demand, you need an infrastructure that matches your needs. A solution that offers vendor independence is key.

SAP HANA Cloud offers multi-cloud flexibility so you can run on your hyperscaler of choice. The cloud-native architecture runs on Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Platform, Microsoft Azure, Alibaba Cloud, and soon, SAP data centers. You can choose a hyperscaler without fear of vendor lock-in.

 

Because it uses cloud-native technologies, the architecture offers consistent, high performance no matter which provider you choose. Automated failover and recovery features enhance resilience. Database administrators can provision new instances in just minutes. And elastic scaling capabilities respond to changing workload demands in real time.

SAP HANA Cloud also reduces the complexity of database operations. It simplifies integration across hybrid or multi-cloud environments and provides direct access to data in SAP applications. Because SAP HANA Cloud is a fully managed database-as-a-service (DBaaS) from SAP, your IT personnel are free to focus on value-added tasks. What’s more, SAP HANA Cloud covers your database, infrastructure, and management requirements, eliminating the need for a separate infrastructure contract with your hyperscaler.

The IDC study assessed the financial impact of infrastructure independence and the associated flexibility. After deploying SAP HANA Cloud, study participants reported a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams and said that database deployments were executed 38% faster. Considering the costs of IT staff management, unplanned downtime, and database infrastructure, IDC calculated a 35% lower annual total cost of ownership for SAP HANA Cloud over a three-year period.

According to one study participant with a large database environment,

“SAP HANA Cloud has enabled us to redirect IT staff to focus more on the production environment, new development, integration, and leveraging AI. Overall, this allows them to help drive revenue and increase productivity.”

Next-generation application foundation

To gain business value from modern, intelligent applications, you need a sophisticated database that can support multiple data types from various sources, process data in real time, and deliver insightful analytics.

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, an open cloud platform with data management, analytics, AI, IoT, blockchain technologies and application development services. Together, SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP form a full-stack solution that includes powerful integration features and an intuitive interface, all under one commercial model.  In addition, SAP HANA Cloud is the trusted database that powers SAP’s mission-critical solutions, such as SAP Business Cloud, with multi-model engines and enterprise-grade performance and reliability.

SAP HANA Cloud also empowers developers to create intelligent applications using today’s most advanced technologies. With this database, teams can build applications that use generative AI, machine learning, and specialized engines to handle vectors, knowledge graphs, property graphs, and spatial processing. It also manages semi-structured JSON data with ACID compliance. The resulting applications are context-aware and offer secure connections to critical business data and curated data products from SAP.

This integrated approach allows applications to ingest and process data in multiple formats and from various sources, including SAP and third-party solutions. Users get live access to critical business information without data replication. Native connectivity to various data sources unifies disparate data streams, offering a single holistic view of your enterprise data. Applications can respond to events in real time, support automated processes, and enable ad-hoc decision-making using current and historical data.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #3 in the Series
entry.content:
Welcome back to my blog series on the value of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In the first two blogs, I discussed how features such as multi-model engines, infrastructure independence, and a next-generation application foundation all can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

In fact, we’ve already seen powerful confirmation of the value of this database. For example, global consulting services provider CONTAX Inc. migrated to SAP HANA Cloud to gain the elasticity and scalability it needed to handle huge demands on its database resources. This modernization helped CONTAX expand its database capacity while reducing its overall memory footprint and cost by 25%.

That’s impressive. So how can you best estimate the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud for your enterprise?

Many organizations want to migrate their database to the cloud because they want to build and deploy intelligent applications at scale. But that requires an advanced data landscape architecture—a database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for modernizing your applications. Let’s talk about two capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud that help you meet that need and deliver exceptional value: intelligent data tiering and multi-dimensional elastic scalability.

Intelligent data tiering

The exploding growth of business data is both a cost issue and a management challenge for your business. How can you store the data users need and make it easily accessible without busting the budget?

Traditional database technology requires that you choose between database performance and costs. Should you pay more to over-provision storage space so data can be easily persisted in case of growing demands? Or should you archive data to save money but make data harder to access?

With SAP HANA Cloud, you can strike the right balance for your business.

 Intelligent, multi-temperature data management features help you store data in tiers according to type, operational usefulness, access frequency, and scalability requirements. The database locates frequently accessed, business-critical “hot” data in high-performance, in-memory storage, which facilitates real-time processing. “Warm” data requiring moderate access uses disk storage. Infrequently accessed “cold” data can be stored in a lower-cost data lake optimized for long-term retention and compliance.

By combining tiered storage with advanced virtualization capabilities, SAP HANA Cloud reduces cost and complexity while enabling optimum overall performance. Applications and users can query data at any tier without needing to know where the data is stored. Automatic optimization based on data location and access patterns eliminates complex, costly ETL processes—while supporting both operational efficiency and analytical depth. Data tiering also simplifies application development by offering one interface to multiple data tiers. Developers can use that interface to query data for applications without needing to know where the data is stored.

A recent IDC study [1] assessed database performance impacts for organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Query speed and response time improved by 31% and 29%, respectively. Backups executed 27% faster. Both data load time and recovery time were 24% faster.

“Data is more accessible with SAP HANA Cloud,” said one study participant. “It is also available in real time and loads far quicker than our previous environment. Our data performance has enhanced.”

Multi-dimensional elastic scalability

Another way SAP HANA Cloud helps you balance performance and cost is by enabling elastic scalability for data processing and storage across multiple dimensions. In today’s dynamic database environments, short-term processing peaks caused by issues such as period-end reporting surges, seasonal transactions, or heavy analytics workloads can create havoc.

Elastic scalability lets you adjust compute and storage resources based on workload demands, in real time. The database ramps up resources during periods of high demand and then reduces them during low-usage times to conserve costs. Flexible resources include:

  • Performance classes, with flexible CPUs and memory ratios
  • Elastic compute nodes, on-demand resources provisioned in minutes for data-intensive OLAP workloads
  • Dynamic scalability, with individual storage tiers that allow the database to grow or shrink as needed

SAP HANA Cloud also includes elasticity features such as class-based dynamic workload routing, which automatically sends queries to the most appropriate compute resources. An ECN advisor analyzes historical workload patterns and creates optimal provisioning schedules. To prevent scaling events from disrupting application performance, SAP HANA Cloud offers built-in monitoring and workload routing capabilities.

These elastic scalability features help you respond rapidly to changing business needs, enabling optimal performance without over provisioning resources. These features make data more accessible to users while reducing infrastructure complexity. Together, they can help you drive operational agility and cost-effective resource management.

With these benefits in mind, IDC evaluated the infrastructure costs of surveyed companies that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Using its business value methodology, IDC concluded that the infrastructure costs of an SAP HANA Cloud environment were 20% less than a comparable database environment over a three-year period.

According to one study participant operating in the retail industry, “SAP HANA Cloud has given my organization the ability to scale and reduce redundancy, which are significant benefits.”

entry.title: How to configure SAML SSO for SAP HANA Cockpit -with Database Groups&Resource Ids as SAML Attributes
entry.content:
Starting with SAP HANA Cockpit 2.0 SP8 (2.8.5), it is possible to grant access to SAP HANA Cockpit database groups or resources via SAML attributes. With such configuration, you can assign the accessibility of different database groups or resources to different IdP users.

In this article, we use SAP Cloud Identity Service as Identity Provider service. If you are using other 3rd-party IdPs, ensure the custom SAML attributes are supported and can be sent to SAP HANA XSA UAA.

In addition to this article, you can also have a reference in below documentation about the setting up SAML SSO to SAP HANA Cockpit, when it is not required to restrict the database group shown for specific cockpit users. 
How to Configure SAP HANA Cockpit with SAP Cloud Platform Identity Authentication Step-by-Step Configure SSO Access to the SAP HANA Cockpit | SAP Help Portal

Prerequisites:

  • SAP HANA Cockpit has been installed and running.
  • An administration account in SAP HANA Cockpit is available, i.e. COCKPIT_ADMIN.
  • Identity Provider service application is available for use. 

Procedures:

Section 1. Preparation in HANA Cockpit Manager

In this section, you may consider creating or assigning expected database groups and registered database resources for IdP users.

  1. Open HANA Cockpit Manager with an administration user, i.e. COCKPIT_ADMIN or XSA_ADMIN, navigate to “Database Groups”.

  2. Create database groups and assign Databases to the group.



  3. Note down the Resource IDs (ResID) of the Databases that the IdP user is expected to access.
    Go to Registered Databases – Select the Database resource and find the ResID at the end of the URL.


    In above screenshot, ResID = 49623.

     

Section 2. (Optional) Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part I - User setup

  1. Note: If the user is expected to access all database groups, then you can skip this section.
    Configure user attributes
    1. In SAP IDS, click Menu Tab “Users & Authorizations” – select “User Management”



    2. Search for the IdP user account, click to open the user configuration.
      Verify whether there’s correct email address maintained.
    3. Expend the drop-down of “Details”, click to navigate to “Custom Attributes”

    4. Enter the Database Group Name of this user in “Custom Attribute 1”. E.g. SYSTEMDBs



    5. To specify Database Resources, enter the ResID (resource ID) of each database resources, delimited by comma in “Custom Attribute 2”.  The ResID can be found in the way introduced in Section 1 – Step 3.

      For example, 49623 for SYSTEMDB@H78.

      • If multiple database groups or resources need to be mapped, use comma-separated list without spaces.



      • If the user expects to enter all Database Resources under this Database Group, leave the “Custom Attribute 2” as blank.

Section 3. Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part II – Setup Groups and Download Metadata

In this documentation, we use SAP Cloud Identity Service (SAP IDS) as Identity Provider, you can also use other IdP alternatively.

  1. Groups Setup
    1. Access SAP Cloud Identity Service, create “Groups” under “Users & Authorizations”.


      Create below Groups.
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER
      • IDP_USER
      • HANA_COCKPIT_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_RESOURCE_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_POWER_USER





    2. After creating the Groups, your account can be seen as a member of the group.



      As administrator, the authorizations of the IDP user can be controlled by assigning different groups to the user.
      You can access User Management, search for the user ID, and open the Groups tab.

      *The creation (and mapping) of Groups depends on the corresponding Role collections that the IDP user expects.





      For example, a user is able to access HANA Cockpit with specific Database Group or Resources with below Groups assigned.
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER
      • IDP_USER

  2. Download the metadata of the Identity Provider service.
    1. Go to “Applications & Resources” – “Tenant Settings”



    2. Select “Single Sign-On” – “SAML 2.0 Configuration”



    3. Click “Download Metadata File” and save the Metadata File to local.

Section 4. Configuration in XSA Cockpit

  1. Open the XSA Cockpit in web browser.
    The url can either be found from the API URL:




    Or it can be found from the xs apps list:



    Login as an administration account, e.g. COCKPIT_ADMIN or XSA_ADMIN.

  2. (Optional) Create IDP Role, Role Collection and Role Mappings
    Note: If there’s no requirement for IDP user to access HANA Cockpit with specific Database Groups and Resources, then you can pass this step.
    1. Navigate to left menu bar Security – Role Collections – New Role Collection
      Name: IDP_USER



      Currently, there’s no Role assigned to it.

    2. Navigate to left menu bar Organizations – E.g. HANACockpit – the Space where Cockpit installed, E.g. SAP, find Application cockpit-persistence-svc, click to open the configuration of this Application.



    3. Navigate the left menu bar Security – Roles, create a new Role.



      Name: IDP_USER
      Template: COCKPIT_IDP_USER
      Attributes:
      ResourceGroups  - Identity Provider (SAML) – ResourceGroups
      Resources - Identity Provider (SAML) – Resources



      Save.

    4.  

      Assign this Role to the Role Collection
      You can see the Role IDP_USER just collected, click the “+” button.



      Select IDP_USER Role Collection which we created in Step 2.a.  And Save.



  3. Create IdP Trust Configuration
    1. Go to the Home page of XSA Cockpit, e.g. Click “Home”.



    2. Navigate to left menu bar “Security” – “IdP Trust Configuration” – Click “New Trust Configuration”



    3. Click the “Upload” button and upload the IdP Metadata xml file downloaded in Section 3 – Step 2.c.


      No need for other modification at this step. Then Save.

  4. Create Role Mappings
    1. Click to enter the Identity Provider just created. Navigate to “Role Collection Mappings”





    2. Create New Rolle Collection Mapping to map the Role Collection to the Groups create in SAP Cloud Identity Service in Section 3 - Step 1.





      For other Groups, the Role Collection Mappings are as below:



  5. Download SAP HANA Cockpit metadata.
    1. Go back to “Security” – “IdP Trust Configuration”, click “Show UAA trust metadata”



    2. Copy and paste the content to local and save as .xml, E.g. Cockpit_Metadata.xml

There’s another way to download the SAP HANA Cockpit metadata, which is to open below URL directly in web browser.
https://<fqdn>:3<instance number>32/uaa-security/saml/metadata

Section 5. Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part III – IdP setup

  1. Create Application for SAP HANA Cockpit in SAP IDS
    1. Open the Identity Provider service, access “Applications & Resources” – Applications



    2. Create your Application for SAP HANA Cockpit



    3. In the Application, click “SAML 2.0 Configuration” under Trust tab – Single Sign-On section



    4. Import the metadata of SAP HANA Cockpit
      Click “Upload Metadata”



    5. Select the metadata .xml file, i.e. Cockpit_Metadata.xml downloaded in Section 4 - Step 5. Download SAP HANA Cockpit Metadata, and “Upload”. No need to maintain the Endpoints.



  2. Configure the Subject Name Identifier
    1. Go back to the Application created for SAP HANA Cockpit, click to enter “Subject Name Identifier” under Trust tab – Single Sign-On section.



    2. Set the Primary Attribute as
      Source: Identity Directory
      Value: Email



  3. Configure IdP Attributes
    1. Go back to the Application for SAP HANA Cockpit, click to enter “Attributes”.



    2. Add Attribute - Groups
      Name: Groups
      Source: select “Identity Directory”
      Value: select “All Groups” from the drop-down list



    3. Add Attribute - ResourceGroups
      Name: ResourceGroups
      Source: select “Expression”
      Value: enter “${customAttribute1}”

    4. Add Attribute - Resources
      Name: Resources
      Source: select “Expression”
      Value: enter “${customAttribute2}”

      Then “Save”.

Now all configuration is done, you can test the SAML SSO by launching SAP HANA Cockpit and single sign-on with IdP. Then the mapped database group is shown on top of other tiles.

entry.content:
SAP S/4 HANA: -

SAP S/4 HANA is the latest version of SAP. The full form of SAP S/4 HANA is SAP Business Suite 4th generation ERP High Performance Analytic Appliance.
There are 3 layers that are present in SAP namely:-  
1. Presentation layer
2. Application Layer
3. Database Layer

In the 1990’s a new architecture was introduced, and it was R/3. In R/3 architecture we can observe the three layers namely presentation layer, application layer and database layer.

The speed of R/3 architecture is fast when compared with R/2 architecture. The algorithms in R/2 architecture were in the database layer whereas the algorithms in R/3 architecture are in the application layer. The database layer can be anyone like oracle, Microsoft etc...FIG : - R/3 Architecture

1. Presentation Layer:-
The presentation layer is a screen where user can interact with the system. For example we can take Monitor of a computer or laptop screen. So for SAP it is GUI --> Graphical User Interface. Here user will interact with SAP data base with the help of SAP GUI which is a software that will be installed on laptops.

2. Application Layer:-
This is the main advantage of SAP R/3 architecture. Here it acts as like middle wear between presentation layer and database layer. Here it will process the user input , applies business rules and execute the programs in this layer.
Here in this layer it will collects all the details or actions that are being carried out by the user and interacts with the database system and represents them on the output screen.

Dispatcher:- Dispatcher will collects the request and will decide which type of request it is whether it is dialog, update, background, spool , enqueue. After getting to know about the spool request type it will also check for the work processor which is idle.
Work Processor:- After getting the request into work processor it will co-ordinate with the database management and will perform the operation or action on the database and will also gets a acknowledgement .

3. Database layer:- 
After getting the request or command form the database management the database layer will process it and will update the request.

The below diagram is the in-depth process of how the database layer will function.

DATABASE LAYER FUNCTION FLOW: - 

  • The request from the work processor will first enter into the session manager and the session manager will makes user to automatic behaviour and transaction isolation level.
  • Once the request got established the request moves to the planning engine which analyses SQL.
  • And here SQL engine will runs the machine.
  • The transaction manager assigns a transaction ID and ensures that every operation follows the principle, transactions to the SQL engine and data engine.
  • The data engine takes over the user request and performs it on the database.
  • Index Server → Executes SQL/MDX queries, does actual processing.
  • Name Server → Knows where the data lives.
  • Pre-processor → Text & search.
  • XS Engine → Application services.
  • Persistence Layer → Save points + logs.

entry.title: Backup & Restore Approach for SAP HANA Systems with Encryption Enabled
entry.content:
Hello Guys,

This blog is related to backup restore approach of sap hana system when encryption is enabled.

So, the first question is: What is encryption in backup and restore?
Backup encryption protects the contents of data backups, log backups, and delta/differential backups using the AES-256 encryption algorithm. The encryption is performed using Backup Encryption Root Keys (BEKs), which are 256 bits in length.

If ENCRYPTION is enabled for backups, restoring or refresh of that backup is slightly different from the normal process.

First, we need to verify if backup ENCRYPTION is enabled using the following command:

SELECT * FROM M_ENCRYPTION_OVERVIEW;

If encryption is enabled for backup, we cannot directly restore the encrypted backup. We will need the SSFS root key used to encrypt the backup.

Process to Check the Encryption Keys Used for Backup & Log Encryption

How can I find out if the instance SSFS contains the root keys used to encrypt backups

/usr/sap/H46/HDB00/exe/hdbnsutil -printHashedRootKeys --dbid=<dbid> --verbose

In the above screenshot keys are mentioned by which backup, logs are encrypted, this is just for our reference.

Here in the above screenshot dbid is there, we can find dbid by executing below command from SYSTEMDB.

SELECT DATABASE_NAME, CASE WHEN (DBID = '' AND DATABASE_NAME = 'SYSTEMDB') THEN 1 WHEN (DBID = '' AND DATABASE_NAME <> 'SYSTEMDB') THEN 3 ELSE TO_INT(DBID) END DATABASE_ID FROM (SELECT DISTINCT DATABASE_NAME, SUBSTR_AFTER (SUBPATH,'.') AS DBID FROM SYS_DATABASES.M_VOLUMES);

Just for the knowledge purpose where is instance SSFS located on to the hana server.

The default path to the key file (SSFS_<SID>.DAT)  of the instance SSFS is

$DIR_GLOBAL/hdb/security/ssfs.

Note : Never manually change any of the files related to the instance SSFS. For all administrative tasks related to instance SSFS, use the SAP HANA tool hdbnsutil.

/usr/sap/SID/HDB<instance number>/exe/hdbnsutil.

If you already have root key backup and key passphrase by which backup encrypted then its easy for you to restore, otherwise you have to follow below steps .

Backup Root keys 

-----------------------------

Below are the steps for exporting the root keys from the instance SSFS:

  1. The encryption root key backup is secured using a passphrase, which must be set before creating the SSFS key backup (export).

  2. To set the passphrase, the system privilege ENCRYPTION ROOT KEY ADMIN is required.

  3. Use the following SQL statement to set the encryption root key backup passphrase:

  4. ALTER SYSTEM SET ENCRYPTION ROOT KEYS BACKUP PASSWORD "<passphrase>";

As per the above image root key password has been changed for both systemDB & tenantDB.

Once the passphrase is set, you can export the encryption root key from the source system.

To backup the encryption root keys, use export root key functionality.
/usr/sap/H46/HDB00/exe/hdbnsutil -backupRootKeys <filename>.rkb --dbid=<dbid> --type='ALL'

Importing Source system Root Keys into Target System.

you need to import the source system’s backup root keys into the target system. However, before importing the source root key, ensure that you take a backup of the target system’s encryption keys.

First transfer & validate the password for the source system root key backup file ( *.rkb) in target system before import.
/usr/sap/H46/HDB00/exe/hdbnsutil -validateRootKeysBackup <filename>.rkb.

To import the source system root key file into target, make sure target database must be offline, otherwise you will get below error message

Import the backup encryption root keys by using following command.

./hdbnsutil -recoverRootKeys <filename>.rkb --dbid=<dbid> --type=<type>

now validate backup root key for both system before starting actual restore of database.

dbid 4 backup key and dbid 3 backup key both are same now.

Now we are ready to proceed with the restore using the normal process, as the source root keys have been successfully imported into the target system.

I performed this on my trial system. Before carrying out any activities related to encryption root keys in your environment, it is strongly recommended to review 2444090 - FAQ: SAP HANA Backup Encryption - SAP for Me

Thank you for reading! Feel free to drop comments or questions — I’d be happy to help.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #4 in the Series
entry.content:
We’ve been talking in this about how you can build your business case for modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. However, many organizations still need help calculating the business value of migrating their database to the cloud.

A recent IDC study [1]  confirmed the value of modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. Using a detailed business value assessmt methodology, IDC calculated that each SAP HANA Cloud database delivered US$820,000 in average annual benefits, with a 10.3-month payback on investment. Numbers like that are sure to turn heads.

This blog reviews the three beneficial features that can help you make the case for SAP HANA Cloud: native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines the duties of database developers and administrators.

Native AI capabilities

To gain value from huge volumes of business data, you need advanced AI capabilities that simplify the development and deployment of intelligent applications. 

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, which offers powerful AI tools, frameworks, and services. These capabilities streamline the development and deployment of intelligent applications using machine learning and generative AI features. Extensive tools and resources, including prebuilt AI models, help you take advantage of business-ready AI.  

Multi-model engines process vast amounts of data and generate intelligent, in-context outputs. SAP HANA Cloud provides native storage, processing, and querying capabilities for AI data. A built-in vector engine handles embeddings as core data, so you can conduct similarity searches and rankings without creating separate vector databases. The database also supports retrieval-augmented generation, which helps large language models become more context-aware and integrate sensitive business context into data interactions.

SAP HANA Cloud also includes built-in, AI-enabled analytics that support predictive modeling, graph and similarity search, and time-series analysis. A predictive analysis library supports powerful features such as clustering, recommender systems, and outlier detection.  In addition, a library of 100+ business and scientific algorithms for key ML scenarios is embedded natively into the database. The IDC report suggests organizations can use these capabilities to automate insights and optimize decision-making by processing multiple data types. Study participants realized a 25% productivity increase, which translates into a value of $271,184 per enterprise.

Global cosmetics leader Natura &Co used the AI capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to create a similarity search. The vector engine feature of SAP HANA Cloud allows users to extract information from large volumes of documents using natural language. The company also plans to use the generative AI capability to streamline business processes and support faster decision-making in its implementation of SAP S/4HANA.

Built-in data integration

Your IT landscape is complex—with data flowing to and from multiple systems, cloud platforms, and on-premises environments. Bringing this data together has always required complex ETL processes, synchronization mechanisms, and data duplication efforts. How can you simplify the integration of this business data? Realistically, every business uses data sources provided by various vendors. To bring this data together requires smooth data integration.

SAP HANA Cloud offers native connectivity with almost any data source. You can access data from SAP and third-party applications, including ERP systems, IoT devices, and external data services. The database can gain live access to sources without data replication. This integration unifies disparate data streams and creates one holistic view of your enterprise data, allowing developers to build intelligent data applications that deliver accurate, current information in real time.  

Built-in data integration capabilities include:

  • Smart data access, offering virtual data access from source systems without physical data movement
  • Simple switching between virtual data access and data replication, balancing cost and performance effectively
  • Smart data integration, enabling real-time or batch data replication with transformation capabilities
  • Hybrid connectivity, with unified connection to on-premises SAP HANA systems

Multi-model capabilities combine federated relational data with other data types, including vector embedding, spatial information, graph relationships, and JSON documents. By eliminating traditional barriers between data sources and locations, SAP HANA Cloud helps you simplify data management while creating a connected enterprise data ecosystem.

In the IDC report, respondents said the ability to gain access to real-time data from a single source helped their analytics teams accelerate data reporting. One executive working in the retail industry said, “The data is far more accessible and quicker to get with SAP HANA Cloud.”

Automation to streamline DBA duties

The workload of database developers and administrators seems to grow endlessly, as data architectures become more complex. Whether they are diagnosing and resolving issues, tuning database performance, or writing queries, these workers face a long list of highly manual tasks.

Using integrated, AI-powered tooling available with SAP HANA Cloud helps administrators work more efficiently and productively. Conversational AI features help them generate SQL statements from plain text queries, create intelligent explanations of database behaviors or issues, and automatically summarize alerts and system messages into actionable insights.

SAP HANA Cloud also automates routine database maintenance issues. The database continuously monitors system usage and offers proactive recommendations for optimization. It can identify performance bottlenecks, guide resource tuning, and suggest areas ripe for elastic scaling. Administrators can get the job done with no deep technical intervention required. 

The benefits of automation are notable. In the IDC study, companies reported a 30% efficiency boost for their database administrator (DBA) teams, resulting in an average annual business value of $336,089 per organization.

One technology organization appreciated this value. “SAP HANA Cloud provides our DBA team with more tools to help identify issues and resolve them,” said the participant. “It has increased their productivity as a result.”

Another company in the agriculture industry concurred. “The fact that SAP HANA Cloud has centralized database administration and provided flexibility to add a data lake within its data source connections has positively impacted the productivity of our DBA team,” the executive added.

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the final blog to learn how comprehensive security and a complete development system can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

entry.title: Half the World Away: A Geospatial Cautionary Tale
entry.content:
More than just a great Oasis song... this is a special case to watch out for when using HANA Geospatial features. This will be obvious to some, but here is something not particularly well documented, and I felt it was worth sharing.

 

So far but yet so close

I'd been playing around with HANA's Geospatial features. The challenge of the day was joining information from about 100,000 weather stations around the globe with nearby world cities. Part of this meant holding geo-coordinate information (i.e. Longitude and Latitude pairs) in columns with data type ST_POINT(4326) – the WGS84 international standard, and using the ST_DISTANCE method to return the distance between them. Easy enough.
 
Soon, I noticed something strange – although almost every city/station pair I had was behaving as expected, for a small handful I was getting some nonsensical results. Here are three such examples, along with a sensible result for Heidelberg (sorry SAP, Walldorf wasn’t in my table).

In the first example, my query was telling me that the nearest weather station to Auckland, New Zealand was in Moron de la Frontera... a Spanish Air Force Base… on the other side of the globe. And it thought that the distance was exactly zero.

My immediate assumption was that I had done something stupid in my select statements, or had formatted some data wrong. Wanting to sanity check, I looked up the co-ordinates for each area.

  • Auckland: (174.764980799, -36.850013)
  • Spanish weather station: (-5.6, 37.1833 ).

A quick check on Google maps showed that this was indeed correct… certainly both in their respective neighbourhoods.
So the co-ordinates seemed okay, and I even didn’t fall into the trap of getting the longitude/latitude order wrong.
(for the uninitiated, ST_POINT has these in (long,lat) order, the opposite of the more common way of presenting, which has (lat,lon). Something I find slightly annoying!)
Clearly something else was the matter...

Reproducing the issue

I thought it would be a good idea to try manually constructing the points, in case my SELECT or Calculation View logic was faulty. This also gave a distance of zero.

Now let’s move one of the points ever so slightly….


Holy moly! Now we see the correct distance of about 20,000 km.

What happened? All we did was shift one of the points about 5 km – you can see on the map it’s still in the same area.

So what’s going on? Is it because military bases are somehow restricted areas on the WGS84 standard?
Hmm… probably not. Let’s try with another one of my pairs which did not work.

Here’s the city of Shenzhen, China (114.122123099, 22.55237051):

And a weather station in La Quiaca, a sleepy town on the Argentina/Bolivia border. (-65.6, -22.1):


Again, these points manually give a distance of zero.

Antipodes

At this point, I saw that the Wikipedia article for La Quiaca has an interesting sentence:

“an approximate antipode to Hong Kong”.

^see, I told you...

For those unfamiliar with Asian geography, let’s zoom out of Shenzhen and see where it is…

Aha... right next to Hong Kong. So we seem to have found the culprit.

In all cases, the pairs which were showing as zero distance were about as far away as it is possible to get on the other side of the globe.

In these extreme situations, distance formulae tend to break down a little. Let's dig further into this.

Vincenty's Formula

I believe the implementation of ST_DISTANCE in SAP HANA uses Vincenty’s Inverse Formula which you can read all about here.

The math may not mean much to you, but there is a little caveat at the end worth noting:

“Between two nearly antipodal points, the iterative formula may fail to converge”. In other words… the equation fails for points on the opposite side of the globe.


That's exactly what happened here.

To further back this up, I found an online calculator with an explicit use of Vincenty’s Formulae here

It comes with a similar warning:

Vincenty’s inverse solution can fail on nearly antipodal points. Testing with Geographic­Lib test data, I’ve found this can happen with distances greater than 19,936 km, or within around 75 km of the antipodal point.

And sure enough, my co-ordinate pairs are throwing a 'Not a Number' error.

 

Final Words

So there you have it. If you are implementing any similar Geospatial projects, be sure to double-check and protect against antipodal failures.

In my case, I made a separate view to show the pairs giving exactly zero distance and manually confirmed the results.

I hope this saves someone a headache one day.
Good luck, and happy bug hunting!

-Elliott

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #5 in the Series
entry.content:
This is the final chapter in this blog series on the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I’ve described key features that offer significant benefits for your organization and can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

Although it can be difficult calculating the business value of migrating your database to the cloud, the expertise of independent organizations can be helpful. A recent IDC study[1]  used a specialized business value methodology to assess the benefits of SAP HANA Cloud delivered to participating organizations. IDC concluded that the benefits were worth an annual average of US$13.7 million per organization and that the database enabled a 35% three-year reduction in total cost of ownership.

If you don’t have time to read this report, I encourage you to complete your own organization assessment using our free tool. In less than five minutes, you’ll receive useful insights that can help you decide your next steps.

 

Let’s consider two more features of SAP HANA Cloud that can help you realize significant business value: comprehensive security and a complete application development ecosystem.

Comprehensive security

Protecting your data and helping ensure compliance are top concerns for every organization. As business operations and workforces become more distributed, the need to provide secure data access from anywhere in the world intensifies.

SAP HANA Cloud offers robust security features that cover critical data protection areas, including authentication, authorization, user management, data masking, anonymization, and encryption. Because these features are built into the database, you have little or no need for third-party security tools. These capabilities also reduce the administrative effort needed to protect data.

Support for multiple security certifications and standards, such as ISO (International Organization for Standardization) and SOC (Standard Occupational Classification), helps ensure regulatory compliance. Configurable audit policies streamline compliance activities while helping protect your business and your customers. Automated updates to libraries and applications also boost security.

These features help make it faster and simpler to meet your security goals. According to the IDC report, the security teams of organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud increased efficiency by 19%. This benefit translates into an average annual business value of $183,016 per organization.

One study participant from the agriculture industry cited the database security standards and policies of SAP HANA Cloud, considering it an extra protective layer to reinforce security. “If we had an on-premises database, we’d lack this added protection,” said the interviewee. “The entire platform has policies that prevent mistakes. For instance, SAP now requires updates to libraries and applications for security reasons. These requirements from SAP keep us updated and secure.”

Another participant from the healthcare industry viewed the advanced protection as a financial advantage. “SAP HANA Cloud is a much more secure system that makes data more accessible and applications perform faster,” he said. “This has helped us meet our customers’ needs much better and has improved our revenue by about five percent.”

A complete application development ecosystem

Time and resources are tight for your development teams. Demand from business users has never been higher, new use cases are emerging, and the need for different developer skill sets seems to continually grow.

SAP HANA Cloud can help address these challenges with an integrated development ecosystem based on SAP Build solutions. SAP Build offers a comprehensive group of tools that support the full spectrum of no-code/low-code, pro-code, and generative AI development approaches. With SAP Build and SAP HANA Cloud, you can support developers at any skill level with the right tools.

Developers can build intelligent applications that use generative AI and harness their expertise and data. Applications built on SAP HANA Cloud can use intelligent algorithms to process large volumes of data and provide actionable recommendations. SAP HANA Cloud also includes machine learning libraries that help developers build sophisticated analytics applications that augment user expertise. By incorporating AI-driven insights, these applications help you anticipate future trends and predict behaviors, make business decisions faster, and improve business performance.

The IDC report found that these application development capabilities deliver quantifiable business value. IDC estimates that development team productivity spiked by 30% in the surveyed organizations, creating staff time savings of $361,519 per organization.  

SAP HANA Cloud features, such as information libraries, combined with faster performance and easier integrations, helped developers build more complex applications such as those using machine learning and AI. Overall, participants developed or deployed 154% more features and applications annually than they could without SAP HANA Cloud.

One study participant explained the impact of this value on the development team. “SAP HANA Cloud provides developers with more seamless integrations, and it is easy to use,” the interviewee explained. “They spend less time writing code because they can reuse code and use the libraries.”
